title: Building License (Licencia de Obras): What It Means for Buyers
excerpt: Understand what a Spanish building license is, why it matters for off-plan purchases, and how to verify your new build has proper permits before committing to a purchase.
author: New Build Homes Costa Blanca

content.quickAnswer: A licencia de obras is an official building permit granted by your local town hall (ayuntamiento) before construction begins. For off-plan buyers, verifying this license exists is critical—without it, your property may never receive the first occupation license (LPO), making it impossible to register the deed or obtain utilities.
content.intro: Purchasing an off-plan property in Spain requires understanding a fundamental but often overlooked document: the building license, known as licencia de obras. This permit, issued by the local town hall (ayuntamiento), authorizes construction to proceed according to approved plans. For international buyers on the Costa Blanca—whether investing in Torrevieja, Orihuela Costa, Javea, or Calpe—grasping the significance of this license can mean the difference between securing a legal, registered property and facing years of complications. This comprehensive guide explains what a building license is, why it matters for your purchase, how to verify one exists, the various permit stages, and what happens when builders operate without proper authorization.

sections.title: What Is a Building License (Licencia de Obras)?

subsections.heading: Definition and Legal Framework
subsections.content: A licencia de obras is an official authorization issued by the town hall (ayuntamiento) permitting a builder or developer to commence construction on a property. This is not optional paperwork—it is a legal prerequisite established under Spanish building codes and local urban planning regulations (Plan General de Ordenación Urbana, or PGOU). The license confirms that the proposed construction complies with zoning laws, building codes, environmental requirements, and municipal planning. In Spain's decentralized system, each municipality maintains authority over building permits, so the specific requirements and timelines vary by location. On the Costa Blanca, major municipalities like Torrevieja, Alicante, and Benidorm each operate their own licensing systems. Without this license, construction is technically illegal, regardless of how legitimate the developer appears or how prestigious the project brand is.

subsections.heading: Who Issues and Who Applies for It
subsections.content: The ayuntamiento (town hall) of the municipality where the property is located issues the building license. The application is typically made by the owner of the land or, more commonly, the developer or constructor who has rights over the property. The application process involves submitting detailed architectural plans, engineering reports, environmental assessments (when required), proof of land ownership, and evidence of compliance with the PGOU and other municipal regulations. On the Costa Blanca, well-established developers like Gamma Inmobiliaria or smaller local builders each must navigate these requirements. The license is personal to the project and often lists specific conditions—such as completion deadlines, requirements for water/sewage connections, environmental protections, or contributions to municipal infrastructure (cesiones).

subsections.heading: Key Terminology
subsections.content: Understanding the vocabulary is essential. Licencia de obras (building license) is distinct from other permits: licencia de actividad (activity license for commercial use), licencia de demolición (demolition permit), and later, licencia de primera ocupación (first occupation license). The urbanistic situation (situación urbanística) of a property refers to its compliance status with planning regulations. The PGOU (Plan General de Ordenación Urbana) is the comprehensive urban planning document that dictates what can be built where, building heights, setbacks, density, and permitted uses. Many properties exist in an urbanistic situation that is 'fuera de ordenación' (outside planning), meaning they were built before current regulations—this is less common for new builds but affects many resale properties. For off-plan purchases, the builder should provide documentation showing the urbanistic situation is normal and compliant.

sections.title: Why the Building License Matters for Off-Plan Buyers

subsections.heading: Gateway to Registration and Legal Ownership
subsections.content: The building license is foundational to the entire legal chain of a new property. Without it, the project cannot proceed legally, and more critically, the completed property cannot receive its first occupation license (licencia de primera ocupación or cédula de habitabilidad). Without the LPO, you cannot register the property deed at the Registro de la Propiedad (Property Registry), meaning you never legally own the property—you only have a sales contract. Banks will not release final mortgage tranches without evidence that the completed property can be registered. Insurance companies may refuse coverage. Utilities (water, electricity, gas) cannot be officially connected without an LPO. Essentially, a property without a valid building license and subsequent LPO remains in legal limbo indefinitely. On the Costa Blanca, several high-profile cases have involved off-plan buyers discovering—months or years after signing—that the developer lacked proper permits, leaving them with unsigned deeds and unusable properties.

subsections.heading: Protection Against Developer Default
subsections.content: A legitimate building license indicates that the developer has submitted to municipal oversight and inspection throughout construction. The license imposes conditions, timelines, and obligations on the developer. If the developer abandons the project or goes bankrupt before completion, a licensed project has municipal documentation and evidence of investment, making it easier for buyers to either recover funds or have another builder complete the work. Unlicensed projects offer virtually no recourse—there is no official record of construction authorization, no inspection milestones, and no municipal leverage to ensure completion. For off-plan buyers, a verifiable building license is a critical safeguard. Reputable developers on the Costa Blanca—such as those building large residential complexes in Torrevieja or Orihuela Costa—maintain their licenses prominently in sales documentation and marketing materials precisely because serious buyers demand this assurance.

subsections.heading: Timeline and Completion Confidence
subsections.content: The building license itself contains completion deadlines (plazo de ejecución). Typically, a developer has two to three years to commence construction and must complete the project within a defined period—often four to six years from license issuance. These timelines are not always met, and extensions can be negotiated with the town hall, but the license creates an official timeline. For off-plan buyers, understanding when the license was issued and when it expires provides crucial context for predicting when you might receive your keys. A license issued in 2024 with a four-year completion window suggests delivery around 2028. If a project's license is nearing expiration without completion, this is a red flag. Conversely, a recently issued license suggests the developer is confident and has fresh authorization from municipal authorities.

sections.title: How to Verify a Building License Exists

subsections.heading: Requesting Documentation from the Developer
subsections.content: Your first step is to ask the developer or their sales agent for a copy of the building license. Legitimate developers provide this willingly—it is a selling point. The license document is lengthy and official, issued by the town hall on letterhead with official stamps and signatures. Request not just the original license but any subsequent amendments (modificaciones) or extensions (ampliaciones). A complete file should show when the license was granted, by which authority, what the project specifications are, any conditions imposed, and validity dates. In Torrevieja, for example, major projects typically have licenses issued by the Servicio de Licencias y Disciplina Urbanística. Ask for the license reference number (expediente number) so you can independently verify it if necessary.

subsections.heading: Verifying at the Town Hall (Ayuntamiento)
subsections.content: Once you have the reference number, you can verify the license directly with the municipality. Visit or contact the relevant department (often called Servicios Técnicos de Urbanismo or Licencias de Actividad y Construcción). Provide the reference number, property address, and developer name. You can request an official search or constancia (official certificate) confirming the license exists, its validity dates, and any conditions or penalties attached. In Alicante province municipalities, this service is typically free or costs €5–€15. The town hall will also inform you if the license has been suspended, revoked, or if there are pending inspections. Your Spanish lawyer or gestoría (administrative manager) can perform this verification on your behalf, and most include it as standard practice during due diligence. This step is non-negotiable for off-plan purchases—it costs little and provides immense clarity.

subsections.heading: Checking the Urbanistic Situation
subsections.content: Beyond the building license itself, request a report on the property's urbanistic situation (informe de situación urbanística). This document, obtained from the town hall's urban planning department, confirms whether the property complies with the PGOU, if there are any pending fines or infractions, and whether any administrative proceedings are open against the property or developer. The report typically costs €20–€50 and takes 5–10 working days to obtain. For off-plan properties in well-regulated areas like Orihuela Costa's planned residential zones, the urbanistic situation should be entirely clean. If the report reveals issues—such as excess building above permitted density or setback violations—this indicates either sloppy planning or intentional non-compliance by the developer, both serious concerns. The report is issued in Spanish but your lawyer can interpret it. Always have this report in hand before signing a binding contract.

subsections.heading: Requesting Certificate of No Debts (Certificado de Cargas)
subsections.content: Related to verification is obtaining a certificado de cargas (certificate of charges/debts) from the town hall. This document lists any debts the property or developer owes to the municipality—unpaid taxes, fines, or contributions (cesiones) that were required but not yet paid. If a developer owes €100,000 in mandatory infrastructure contributions and declares bankruptcy before completion, these debts can transfer to the property, affecting your ability to register it or obtain utilities. The certificate costs €10–€20 and is obtained from the municipal finance or contributions department. A clean certificate is essential; any debts should be explained in writing by the developer or their lawyer before you commit funds.

sections.title: Stages of Permits and Construction Oversight

subsections.heading: Initial License and Project Approval
subsections.content: The building license process begins months before ground is broken. The developer submits architectural plans and supporting documentation to the town hall. These are reviewed by municipal engineers, urban planners, and sometimes environmental departments. If approved, the license is granted with conditions. This stage typically takes 2–6 months depending on the municipality's workload and project complexity. In fast-moving areas like Torrevieja, where the town hall processes numerous permits, timelines are often quicker due to experience and streamlined processes. The initial license becomes the legal foundation authorizing construction.

subsections.heading: Construction Permits and Inspections
subsections.content: Once the license is issued, construction begins under municipal oversight. In Spain, construction is subject to periodic inspections (inspecciones de obra) by the town hall or contracted inspectors. These inspections verify that work conforms to the approved plans and building codes. Inspections occur at key stages: foundation, structure, mechanical systems (plumbing, electrical), and final completion. The developer must maintain a construction log (acta de inspección) documenting each inspection's findings. A property with thorough inspection records is a positive sign—it indicates the developer took compliance seriously. For off-plan buyers, you can sometimes request access to inspection reports, though developers occasionally restrict this until completion.

subsections.heading: Environmental and Infrastructure Contributions
subsections.content: Many projects require cesiones (contributions) to the municipality for public infrastructure—roads, parks, water treatment facilities, etc. These are not optional; they are conditions of the license. The developer must execute these works or pay an equivalent contribution to the town hall. If you notice that a project's price per square meter is unusually low relative to competitors, one concern is whether all required cesiones have been budgeted. Underfunded contributions can delay the LPO or create disputes between the developer and municipality. Your lawyer should confirm that all required cesiones are explicitly addressed in the developer's project budget.

subsections.heading: Final Inspection and Completion Certificate
subsections.content: Upon construction completion, the developer requests a final inspection (inspección final de obra) by the town hall. If the inspector approves, a completion certificate (acta de finalización de obra) is issued. This certificate is different from the LPO but is a prerequisite for applying for it. The completion certificate confirms construction has been executed according to the license and plans. Only after this certificate is issued can the developer apply for the first occupation license (licencia de primera ocupación). This stage can take 1–3 months depending on inspector availability and whether any remedial work is required.

sections.title: What Happens If the Builder Lacks a License

subsections.heading: Legal and Administrative Consequences
subsections.content: If a developer constructs without a building license, the property is technically an illegal structure (construcción ilegal). The municipality can order demolition, though this is rare if the developer is solvent and connected locally. More commonly, the municipality issues fines and demands the developer obtain retroactive authorization or licensing (legalización). This process is arduous: the developer must submit current plans, undergo new inspections, and often make modifications to comply with current (not original) regulations. The costs, delays, and uncertainty are substantial. Buyers in such situations face years of limbo, unable to register the property or secure utilities. Several Costa Blanca projects have faced licensing issues; in some cases, affected buyers have organized legal action against developers, but recovery is difficult and protracted.

subsections.heading: Impact on Your Ownership and Financing
subsections.content: A property built without a license cannot receive an LPO, and without an LPO, the deed cannot be registered at the Property Registry. You remain the registered owner only on the sales contract, not on the official property register. This means: your ownership is not legally recognized for inheritance purposes; mortgage lenders will not release final funds; utility companies may refuse connections; insurance is impossible; property taxes may not be recognized; and if the developer declares bankruptcy, creditors can claim the property because it has not been formally transferred to you. For off-plan buyers who have paid 30–50% of the purchase price, this risk is unacceptable. This is why verification of the building license before signing the purchase contract is non-negotiable.

subsections.heading: Recourse Options
subsections.content: If you have already purchased and later discover the license issue, your options are limited. You can demand the developer remedy the situation (obtain retroactive licensing) within a defined period and withhold final payments until this is done. You can demand return of all deposits and cancellation of the contract, though courts are reluctant to enforce this if construction has begun. You can file complaints with consumer protection agencies or the municipality. You can join with other affected buyers to pursue collective legal action. However, all these options are adversarial, costly, and time-consuming. The best protection remains due diligence before signing: verify the license independently, consult your lawyer, and never commit substantial funds without clear documentation.

subsections.heading: What Is the PGOU?
subsections.content: The PGOU (Plan General de Ordenación Urbana) is the comprehensive urban planning document adopted by each municipality. It divides the municipality into zones (suelo urbano, urbanizable, and rústico—urban, developable, and rural land) and specifies what uses are permitted in each. It sets parameters for building height, building volume (occupying no more than a certain percentage of the plot), setbacks from property lines, open space requirements, and density limits (maximum dwelling units per hectare). For residential developments, the PGOU specifies whether apartments, detached villas, or both are permitted; the maximum number of units and their size; required parking; and often contributions for public amenities. A building license confirms that the project complies with the active PGOU at the time of issuance. On the Costa Blanca, PGOUs are regularly updated. Torrevieja's PGOU, for instance, has undergone multiple revisions over the past two decades as the municipality shifted from primarily tourism-focused zones to mixed residential and commercial development.

subsections.heading: How PGOU Compliance Affects Your Purchase
subsections.content: Before signing a purchase contract, understand the PGOU classification of your property. If you are buying a villa in Javea, the PGOU should permit single-family residential use. If you are buying an apartment in a new complex in Benidorm, the PGOU should permit residential apartments at the density proposed. If the PGOU changes after your purchase (rare but possible), your property use is usually grandfathered in. However, if the property was built in violation of the PGOU—say, with more apartments than the PGOU allows—this is a fundamental issue affecting your rights and the property's value. Your lawyer's urbanistic situation report will flag such violations. Never purchase a property with known PGOU non-compliance unless the developer credibly commits to remedying it and provides financial guarantees.

subsections.heading: Sustainable Tourism and Environmental Zones
subsections.content: Many Costa Blanca developments fall within environmental or tourism-focused zones requiring special approvals. For instance, properties near the coast may require environmental impact assessments (EIA). Properties in water scarcity areas may have restrictions on swimming pools or irrigation. Properties in flood-prone zones (recent concern post-DANA in 2023) may require flood-mitigation engineering. These requirements are all part of PGOU compliance and are documented in the building license. Understanding them is important because they affect your use of the property and may require ongoing compliance (e.g., water conservation measures). Your lawyer should highlight any such restrictions, and you should factor them into your purchase decision.

subsections.heading: Expected Timelines for Building Licenses
subsections.content: From application to approval, a building license typically takes 2–6 months in most Costa Blanca municipalities, depending on project complexity and municipal processing speed. For major projects requiring environmental impact assessments or affecting protected areas, 6–12 months is not uncommon. Smaller projects or renovations (obras menores) may be approved in 3–4 weeks. Once approved, the license is valid for a defined period (usually the entire construction period, often 4–6 years). If construction does not begin within 3 years of license issuance, many municipalities require renewal or extension. For off-plan buyers, a newly issued license is preferable; a license approaching its expiration without visible construction progress is concerning.

subsections.heading: Red Flags in Licensing and Permits
subsections.content: Be cautious if: (1) The developer is vague or evasive about providing the building license—legitimate developers volunteer this documentation. (2) The license is very old (issued 5+ years ago) with minimal visible construction—this suggests slow progress or potential issues. (3) The urbanistic situation report reveals debts, fines, or open proceedings against the property or developer. (4) The developer or lawyer cannot clearly explain what cesiones (contributions) are required and how they are funded. (5) Marketing materials prominently feature luxury finishes or amenities but downplay permits and legal compliance—this suggests the developer prioritizes appearance over substance. (6) The project was partially constructed years ago, then abandoned, and is now being relaunched—verify that all original licensing is still valid and that the project matches the original license. (7) The developer is a shell company or fly-by-night operator with no track record in the area—building licenses are issued to named individuals or entities that are ultimately accountable.

subsections.heading: What to Do Before Signing a Contract
subsections.content: Create a pre-contract checklist: (1) Obtain a copy of the building license and verify its authenticity with the town hall. (2) Request and review the urbanistic situation report. (3) Request a certificate of cargas (debts to the municipality). (4) Ask the developer for detailed information on cesiones and when they will be executed. (5) Confirm the projected completion date and how it aligns with the license's validity. (6) Have your lawyer review all documentation and explain any concerns. (7) Understand what happens if the project is delayed—does the developer still have obligations to you? (8) Confirm that the building license number will be referenced in your purchase contract as a representation of the developer. (9) Establish that you have a right to cancel the contract and recover deposits if the building license is revoked or materially changed. (10) Ensure your deposit is protected in a third-party escrow account (cuenta bloqueada), not held directly by the developer. These steps take 2–4 weeks but provide essential protection.

content.conclusion: The building license (licencia de obras) is far more than bureaucratic paperwork—it is the legal foundation of your property. For off-plan buyers on the Costa Blanca, whether you are considering a modern apartment in Torrevieja, a villa in Orihuela Costa, or a coastal property in Javea, verifying that the developer holds a valid building license is non-negotiable. This license authorizes construction, subjects the developer to municipal oversight, and is a prerequisite for the first occupation license without which you cannot register your deed or connect utilities. Take the time to request documentation, verify it with the town hall, and have your lawyer review the urbanistic situation before committing funds. A few hours of due diligence at the outset will save you years of potential complications. Reputable developers welcome this scrutiny; those who deflect or obfuscate should raise serious concerns. Your property is likely the largest investment of your lifetime—ensure its legal foundation is secure from the beginning.
